Award.AwardTitle: New, GK-12: CarbonEARTH (Carbon Educators and Researchers Together for Humanity)

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration: CarbonEARTH (Carbon Educators and Researchers Together for Humanity) will team STEM (science, technology, engineering, mathematics) graduate students with upper elementary and middle school science teachers from rural and urban school districts to present innovative open-inquiry science projects related to the themes of Energy, Matter and Materials, Earth Processes and Ecosystems. The interdisciplinary theme of carbon, broadly construed, will provide a unifying platform for investigation, discovery, training and education. In addition to their ongoing training in research, the CarbonEARTH graduate fellows will be trained in relevant elements of K-12 science teaching, and engage in activities promoting skills in collaboration, organization, communication, teaching, leadership, team building and other transferable skills. CarbonEARTH will additionally facilitate collaboration among faculty and graduate fellows across carbon-related research areas. CarbonEARTH will beneficially provide teachers and students from a wide range of disciplines with science learning experiences that not only teach concepts, but also develop skills for approaching scientific problems, for example global warming, waste disposal, renewable energy and nanoelectronics. The inquiry-based approach will enhance the understanding of STEM concepts and scientific skills for the upper elementary and middle school students, providing experiences that reflect the excitement and importance of STEM careers through their interactions with graduate fellow role models. To address the need to increase the STEM pipeline, throughout the program, priority will be given to supporting STEM education and career retention of underrepresented groups. CarbonEARTH also will strengthen and expand relationships between Penn State and K-12 schools.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The CarbonEARTH (Educators and Researchers Together for Humanity) program teamed Penn State science and engineering graduate student fellows with upper elementary and middle school science teachers from rural Philipsburg-Osceola Area School District and urban Harrisburg Area School District in Pennsylvania to bring innovative open-inquiry science and engineering projects to K-12 students. One goal of the program was to help the CarbonEARTH graduate student fellows learn about teaching and how to communicate their technical research to broad audiences. Another goal was for the teachers to increase their science knowledge and get new ideas for lessons for their classrooms to advance student learning in the STEM (science, engineering, technology, and math) disciplines. The program used the interdisciplinary theme of carbon as a focus for investigation, discovery, and education. Many challenges facing society today involve carbon - including global climate change, waste disposal, renewable energy and nanoelectronics. These issues are frequently addressed in the media, with varying degrees of scientific accuracy. The majority  of K-12 academic standards for science relate to these issues. CarbonEARTH provided teachers and students with science learning experiences that not only taught science concepts, but also developed skills with scientific research and engineering design. These skills allowed teachers and students to look at these problems scientifically and through the lens of many different science and engineering discipline areas.

Over the course of the program, 33 graduate students worked with 19 teachers and their students to design and carry out new lessons related to specific academic and learning outcomes, enabling advances in the learning of STEM disciplines. Senior program personnel who are science education faculty at the Penn State Center for Science and the Schools (CSATS) provided professional training to the CarbonEARTH graduate fellows in science pedagogy, enabling them to design effective lessons, and to engage students in inquiry-based activities in the classroom. A special emphasis was placed on open-ended science or engineering projects, allowing students and teachers to learn more about how scientists and engineers do research. To facilitate this learning, CarbonEARTH science education faculty at CSATS developed a Modeling Authentic STEM Research (MASTER) model based on a systems perspective of research. For the fellows, these teaching experiences increased their skill and comfort level with designing interesting lessons for undergraduate students, K-12 students, and the public. For the teachers, these experiences improved their confidence for implementing inquiry-based and open-ended lessons in their classrooms. Some of the lessons created during these partnerships have been or are in the process of being disseminated via submission to teacher practitioner journals.

CarbonEARTH also focused on developing graduate fellows' communication skills. Throughout the year, fellows attended workshops where they learned how to describe their research to different types of audiences. These audiences rangined from scientists and engineers from disciplines different from their own, to non-technical audiences made up of non-STEM college students. These workshop activities combined with experiences working with elementary and middle school teachers and students greatly improved fellows' ability and comfort level for conveying technical information to any audience.

CarbonEARTH sent six graduate fellows, four teachers, one administrator/graduate student and one STEM education specialist to Germany, the Netherlands, Ethiopia and Tanzania, or Brazil as part of its international activities. Each of these experiences generated excitement about future international collaborations and the benefit of working with scientists and teachers who have a different background and worldview, catalyzing new approaches to STEM research and education.

As a result of the CarbonEARTH program, 33 graduate fellows improved their communication and teaching skills as well as a myriad of other important skills such as organization, leadership and teamwork. These improved skills will benefit not only their own careers, but also their future advisees, undergraduate students, and K-12 teachers and students they may interact with during STEM outreach activities. Nineteen teachers were directly impacted by the program, as were other non-CarbonEARTH teachers at their schools who also used lessons that were developed. Based on the range of grade levels (2nd-8th) and approximate numbers of students in the classes, approximately 1,000 students will be impacted each year by the teacher-fellow partnerships involved in the program.
